text: (gentle music)
- I had rowed, but not seriously.

I wasn't on like a crew
team or anything like that,
and same with the other two co-founders.
Hi, I'm Prasanna, I am the CTO
and one of the co-founders at Ergatta.
At Ergatta, we are building the future
of game-based fitness.
Our core product is a rowing machine
with a connected screen attached to it.
We think about our product as something
that helps you build a fitness routine
and something that is meant to feel

more like a game, or a
sport, than like a class.
My other co-founders and I
wondered why we had so much trouble
making a consistent fitness routine.

And so we thought back to
what made us fit growing up,
and that was playing sports.
It was having fun.
We felt being more like a game

removed the need for
having an instructor there.

You're able to connect to
other people with the visuals.

You're able to connect
to a broader community

knowing that you are
both part of this game.
For fitness to be transformative,
it needs to be engaging,
it needs to fit into their daily lives,
and it needs to become their routine.

So this is how we think
about establishing habits.
And so the cycle of habit building
goes through these phases.

The hardest one are these
two that are circled,

action and maintenance require
the most deliberate effort

and they require effort
in an ongoing basis.
'Cause the way that maintenance develops

is by taking action and
taking action repeatedly.
Iterating is the lifeblood of a startup.

We have to get new code and
new products into market,
we have to test,
and we need to find the right balance
of new technology and mature technology.
We knew that AWS would be catering
to companies at all life cycles.
From early iteration, to alpha to beta,
to launching and scaling,

we knew that there would
be help to make sure

that we were looking
at the right products,
looking at the right services,
and building things in the right ways.
When we think about making a new game,
we start sort of in a big studio

and we ideate on what
games might be interesting.
And then we say, "How would this tailor
to something fitness oriented?"

There's a lot of
experimentation and iteration

then in making sure that we
have a game that's engaging,

but that encourages
good fitness techniques.

We like to think about
both how it could work,
as well as how it could fail.

'Cause we want to make sure
that we aren't just getting
too involved in our own ideas.
We wanna make sure that we're considering
that we have blind spots.

Does it meet any of these
potential failure cases?

'Cause what we found is that
the more we've been able

to be clear-eyed about
mistakes that we've made,
the faster we'll move on from them
and the faster that that mistake
turns into a better product down the line.
Some of these are new ideas
that we haven't done anything with,

and some of them are ideas
we experimented with.
And so we keep them up to make sure
that we are constantly thinking

about what are the ways in
which we can take some things
that have engaged us in the past

and use 'em as inspiration for
what we wanna build tomorrow.
